courseTitle: Quality of Surface Waters: Physical and Chemical

pageData.titleName2: Quality of Surface Waters: Physical and Chemical

pageData.text: Students will collect water samples from local waterways and test them for physical and chemical factors that governments and scientists use to monitor the health of natural waterways.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Bucket or container for waste disposal in field (optional)

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 40 minutes 
 Activity 1: Temperature Measurement - 5 minutes 
 Activity 2: Sample Collection - 5 minutes 
 Activity 3: pH Test - 10 minutes 
 Activity 4: Phosphate Test - 10 minutes 
 Activity 5: Nitrate Test - 10 minutes 
 Activity 6: Turbidity Test - 10 minutes

pageData.text: This lab requires the collection of water samples at two separate sites. Travel time is not included in the times listed below. The times are also ‘per sample’ times.

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Quality of Surface Waters: Physical and Chemical

text: Practice proper water sample collection techniques.
Conduct chemical and physical analyses of field water samples.
Assess the health of local aquatic environments.
Compare water test results to environmental standards.

pageData.text: Agricultural runoff of synthetic fertilizers and untreated human and animal waste increase the concentration of chemicals such as nitrogen and phosphorus in water systems, causing damage at high concentrations. Excess nitrates in particular pose a danger to human health. High levels of nitrates can enter the blood stream, binding with the hemoglobin in red blood cells to create methemoglobin. This molecule carries oxygen less efficiently than hemoglobin and so limits the amount of oxygen carried to cells and tissues.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>Healthy adults can quickly reverse this reaction and restore function. Infants, who are much smaller and have developing systems, can develop methemoglobinemia or “blue baby syndrome”, which can be fatal. Without oxygen, these infants develop bluish-grey skin, as well as lethargy, diarrhea and vomiting.  Most cases of blue baby syndrome occur when infants drink baby formula made with water from a contaminated well. If caught early enough, the condition is easily reversed using the common lab reagent methylene blue; future relapses can be prevented by regularly checking the nitrate levels of any wells used for drinking water<sup>1</sup>.

1Environmental Public Health Office of Drinking Water. (2016, July).
Nitrate in drinking water. Washington State Department of Health.
https://doh.wa.gov/sites/default/files/legacy/Documents/Pubs/331-214.pdf

pageData.desc: A well water pump from which hangs a bucket of water.
pageData.altText: A well water pump from which hangs a bucket of water.

pageData.text: Water is one of the most common and precious compounds on Earth. Water covers approximately 75% of Earth’s surface, but only 2.5% of this is fresh water, and only a small fraction of that 2.5% is accessible for use and consumption.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Three column graphs illustrating the percent composition of total global water, freshwater, and surface water and other fresh water, respectively. The freshwater column is an expansion of 2.5% of the total global water column. The surface water and other fresh water column is an expansion of 1.2% of the freshwater column.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Three column graphs illustrating the percent composition of total global water, freshwater, and surface water and other fresh water, respectively. The freshwater column is an expansion of 2.5% of the total global water column. The surface water and other fresh water column is an expansion of 1.2% of the freshwater column.

pageData.text: We depend on a clean water supply for drinking, cleaning, sanitation, recreation, and manufacturing. Public health officials and biologists have developed tests that can be used to monitor the quality of natural waters and to locate sources (and potential sources) of water pollution. In this activity, you will collect samples from local waterways and test and evaluate water quality based on several characteristics used by scientists to analyze natural waters.

pageData.subTitle: Nitrogen and Phosphorous
pageData.text: Water is an important agent for dissolving and transporting many <button class='glossary-text'>nutrients</button> (essential compounds for life) through the environment. The growth of primary producers (and, by extension, all organisms throughout a food web) in any environment is limited by the scarcity of a resource. That resource can be physical, such as light or space, or it can be a nutrient. In terrestrial and freshwater environments, nitrogen or phosphorous are often limiting nutrients. Most fertilizers contain nitrogen and phosphorus as water-soluble nitrates (NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>) and phosphates (PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3</sup><sup>-</sup>). Rain washes these water-soluble nitrates and phosphates from cultivated land into surface waters where they promote the rapid growth of plants and algae, which speeds up the rate of <button class='glossary-text'>eutrophication</button>. Eutrophication is a natural, usually gradual process that increases sediment and nutrient availability in water bodies. Human activities, however, can lead to cultural, or human-induced, eutrophication which can speed up this normally gradual process. Fertilizer runoff from lawns and farms, inadequately treated municipal wastewater, and poorly maintained septic systems all contribute to cultural eutrophication. In agricultural areas with dense animal populations, animal waste adds nitrogen and phosphorus to surface waters as well.

Heavy rain can cause a sudden influx of <button class='glossary-text'>nutrients</button>, which can lead to rapid and uncontrolled growth in aquatic algae and plant populations. When these organisms die, bacterial-mediated decay depletes water oxygen levels, kills sensitive aquatic organisms, and contributes to sediment buildup. If nitrogen is the limiting nutrient, such as in most brackish or marine waters, nitrogen levels ≥ 0.3 parts per million (ppm) can accelerate natural <button class='glossary-text'>eutrophication</button>. Phosphorous is usually the limiting nutrient in freshwaters. Phosphorus levels ≥ 0.1 ppm can accelerate natural eutrophication in freshwaters.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: A diagram of the eutrophication process.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A diagram of the eutrophication process.

pageData.text: This image is licensed under CC BY 2.0 at https://www.flickr.com/photos/48722974@N07/4859897047

pageData.subTitle: Temperature
pageData.text: Temperature affects many chemical and biological processes. It modifies the solubility of oxygen in water, the rate of photosynthesis in aquatic plants, the metabolic rate of aquatic organisms, and the susceptibility of aquatic species to toxins and disease. Water temperature varies naturally with season and depth, but human activity also can affect temperature in significant ways. For example, heated water from surfaces such as sunlit parking lots, roads, sidewalks, and from industrial processes that use water as a coolant can flow into nearby creeks, streams, or rivers. This thermal pollution can destroy some types of aquatic life. Water loses heat very slowly, so thermally polluted water should be given significant dilution and time to cool before discharged into natural surface waters. Heated water also facilitates the rapid growth of some aquatic plants and algae, so thermal pollution can accelerate the rate of cultural eutrophication.

pageData.subTitle: Dissolved oxygen
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Dissolved oxygen (DO)</button>, or the amount of oxygen in water, is essential for biotic diversity in a body of water. Much of the DO in water comes from the atmosphere. Atmospheric oxygen dissolves via diffusion into the water at the surface. Wind and waves stir the water, which dilutes the DO concentration at the surface by mixing, and subsequently increases the amount of oxygen that can dissolve at the surface. Another important source of oxygen in water is photosynthesis performed by aquatic plants and algae. Some of these aquatic photosynthetic organisms are rooted or attached to the streambed, whereas others are planktonic (live in the water column). The amount of photosynthetically generated DO in the water typically peaks in the afternoon when the sun reaches zenith and the most light penetrates the water. <button class='glossary-text'>Turbidity</button>, or murkiness resulting from a large number of particles in the water, can lower DO levels by reducing photosynthetic rates due to limited light penetration.

Many factors influence the amount of DO that water can hold. Water with lower temperatures can contain higher oxygen concentrations. Freshwater can hold more oxygen than salt water. Another factor is altitude and atmospheric pressure; higher gas pressures result in higher gas concentrations dissolving into a liquid. Atmospheric pressure is greatest at sea level, so more oxygen dissolves into water at sea level than at higher elevations.

The amount of <button class='glossary-text'>DO</button> in a body of water can vary greatly due to all these factors. After a DO measurement is taken from a water sample, a percent saturation value can be calculated by comparing the amount of oxygen the water contains at that moment with the maximum amount of oxygen that it could contain at that temperature.

Respiring organisms, such as animals and bacteria, significantly reduce DO levels as well. Bacteria in animal waste are a major concern in waterways that receive runoff from fields and pastures where livestock are kept. When oxygen becomes depleted in the water, it is said to be anoxic. Anoxic conditions can cause marine organisms to suffocate.

pageData.subTitle: Coliform Bacteria
pageData.text: Coliform bacteria populate the intestinal tract of warm-blooded animals and disperse throughout the environment along with fecal material. When an animal defecates, large numbers of coliform bacteria (called fecal coliforms) are present in the feces. Coliforms also can be released to the environment from a decomposing body. The presence of large numbers of coliforms in a water sample is a good indication that animal or human waste has polluted the water. Most coliforms do not cause disease, except for a few Escherichia coli strains. However, many pathogenic bacteria and parasites are spread through feces (e.g., those causing typhoid fever, hepatitis, gastroenteritis, and dysentery), and the presence of coliforms indicates that harmful pathogens might be present as well. Determining the presence of coliforms in drinking water and in swimming areas is a very important tool for protecting public health.

This is accomplished by collecting a water sample and inoculating some of the sample on <button class='glossary-text'>nutrient</button>-rich medium that supports coliform growth. After several days, the culture will show bacterial growth. This is the first step in determining the risk of animal or human waste contamination of a body of water. Additional tests can be performed to distinguish between total coliforms, which can have several sources, and fecal coliforms, which originate in animal and human intestines. There are potential risks associated with culturing pathogenic bacteria; therefore, this investigation will only examine total coliforms.

pageData.subTitle: Total Suspended Solids
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Total suspended solids (TSS)</button> is a term used to describe and measure the material left behind after a water sample has been filtered and evaporated. Dissolved materials and nutrients in natural water come from a variety of sources. Large concentrations of dissolved solids affect cellular nutrient transport, alter the taste of water, and interfere with industrial processes by fouling pipes and filters. Calcium and magnesium are two minerals commonly dissolved in water. A water-insoluble carbonate forms when aqueous calcium or magnesium hydrogen carbonate is heated. Industrial boilers reach high temperatures and generate solid deposits of magnesium carbonate and calcium carbonate, commonly called scale. These water-insoluble deposits reduce the efficiency of machines and are expensive to remove. TSS measurement requires the use of an analytical balance, which is not practical in the current setting due to cost.

pageData.subTitle: Turbidity
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>turbidity</button> test measures water clarity. Fine particles such as eroded soil, and microscopic organisms such as phytoplankton, contribute to water turbidity. Turbid waters clog fish gills, hinder disinfection processes, and carry entrapped pollutants downstream. Turbidity also blocks sunlight, which prevents photosynthesis below the surface and increases surface water temperature. Turbidity is measured in Nephelometric Turbidity Units (NTU). In this exercise, a modified turbidity tube will be used. A water sample is drained from the tube slowly, and the black and white pattern of a Secchi disk at the bottom of the tube becomes visible. Once the disk becomes visible, the sample volume is recorded and translated into NTU. If the pattern is visible when the tube is full, turbidity will be estimated using a saturation chart.

pageData.subTitle: Biochemical Oxygen Demand
pageData.text: Aerobic bacteria that decompose organic material require oxygen. In general, the more organic material there is in the water, the more oxygen demand will increase. When <button class='glossary-text'>biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)</button>, sometimes called biological oxygen demand, surpasses the amount of oxygen that can be added to the water, the water becomes anoxic. High BOD coupled with low <button class='glossary-text'>DO</button> input causes water quality deterioration, which can result in the death of many fish and animals.

An increase in nitrates and phosphates in a body of water often increases the growth rate of plants and algae. These aquatic organisms subsequently die and are decomposed by aerobic bacteria, which consume oxygen during the process. Another cause of increased BOD is a consequence of fertilizer runoff. An influx of fertilizers and sudden growth of aquatic producers may produce a brief spike in photosynthetically generated DO levels, but BOD rises as the aquatic producers begin to die.

pageData.question: Which of the following is a natural process that can speed up the rate of eutrophication?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Heavy rain can cause a sudden influx of nutrients, which can lead to rapid and uncontrolled growth in aquatic algae and plant populations.

pageData.question: Which of the following can cause an increase in biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Eutrophication can cause an increase in BOD.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In terrestrial and freshwater environments, nitrogen or phosphorous are often limiting nutrients. An increase in nitrates and phosphates in a body of water often increases the growth rate of plants and algae. For example, heavy rain can cause a sudden influx of nutrients, which can lead to rapid and uncontrolled growth in aquatic algae and plant populations. These aquatic organisms subsequently die and are decomposed by aerobic bacteria, which consume oxygen during the process. Another cause of increased biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) is a consequence of fertilizer runoff. An influx of fertilizers and sudden growth of aquatic producers may produce a brief spike in photosynthetically-generated dissolved oxygen (DO) levels, but BOD rises as the aquatic producers begin to die.

pageData.subTitle: pH
pageData.text: Water contains hydrogen ions (H<sup>+</sup>) and hydroxyl ions (OH<sup>–</sup>). The concentration of H<sup>+</sup> ions determines the pH. If the concentration of H<sup>+</sup> ions is higher than that of OH<sup>–</sup> ions, the pH is less than 7.0 and is considered acidic. Thus, the greater the concentration of H<sup>+</sup> ions, the lower the pH will be. If the concentration of H<sup>+</sup> ions is lower than that of OH<sup>–</sup> ions, the pH is greater than 7.0 and is considered alkaline (or basic). The pH scale is from 0 to 14 and is logarithmic; as the pH increases by one whole number, the H<sup>+</sup> ion concentration decreases 10 times. For example, a pH change from 5 to 6 indicates a tenfold decrease in H<sup>+</sup> concentration, and a pH change from 4 to 6 indicates a hundredfold decrease in H<sup>+</sup> concentration.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: A pH scale showing the pHs of common household substances.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A pH scale showing the pHs of common household substances.

pageData.text: Water rarely exists at the neutral pH of 7. Salt water typically is slightly basic, with a pH of 8 or higher. Freshwater usually has a pH of 6.5, but this varies greatly between bodies of water. Organic materials can affect the pH of water. Fallen leaves often contain tannic acid, which stains the water brown and reduces the pH. Some bacteria create acidic waste products that lower the pH of water.

Acid rain has a widespread effect on natural waterways in the eastern United States as well. Oxides of nitrogen and sulfur are released into the atmosphere by burning fossil fuels, and they mix with atmospheric water and form nitric and sulfuric acids. These acids are mixed with rainwater and delivered to natural waterways and soils. Normal rain has a pH of 5.6 due to dissolved carbon dioxide from the atmosphere forming carbonic acid. Rain is known as acidic if the pH is lower than 5.6.

Many freshwater organisms have adapted to a specific pH range. For some organisms, the optimum pH range is quite narrow. A sudden or drastic pH change will kill some of these organisms or reduce survival and reproduction, which disrupts food webs and the aquatic community. Lower pH levels can also release heavy metals from the surrounding bedrock into the water. Once dissolved, these metals can interfere with the uptake of dissolved oxygen by aquatic organisms.

pageData.question: What is the pH of normal rainwater?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Normal rain has a pH of 5.6 due to dissolved carbon dioxide from the atmosphere forming carbonic acid.

pageData.question: Which of the following is LEAST likely to reduce the pH of water in nature?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Water will increase in pH with increased salinity.

Some bacteria create acidic waste products that lower the pH of water. pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 1-4 of this investigation. Before beginning, locate several possible test sites and determine the approximate altitude of each. Then, obtain your field work materials and travel to your test site. In activity 1, submerge the thermometer in the test site water and record the water temperature. In activity 2, rinse the sampling container in the test site water and collect site water. If you are conducting activities 3-6 on site, continue to activity 3. If not, transport your sample home in a cooler, then continue to activity 3. In activity 3, you will add a drop of ample water to the pH paper, compare it to the color chart and record the water pH.  In activity 4, fill the conical tube with sample water, add the LaMotte® Phosphorus TesTab® to the tube and mix the contents. Once a color has developed, compare the tube color to the Sample comparison chart and record the ppm of phosphate in the water sample.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 5 and 6 of this investigation. After completing activity 4, in activity 5, wrap a conical tube in aluminum foil, fill it with sample water, add a LaMotte® Nitrate TesTab® to the tube and mix. Once color has developed, remove the foil, compare the tube color to the Sample comparison chart and record the ppm of phosphate in the water sample. In activity 6, fill the graduated cylinder with 100 mL of water. Then, remove the cylinder from its base and place it over the 0 NTU pattern. Next, observe the pattern through the water. If the pattern is observable, compare the appearance of the 0 NTU pattern through the water to each unobstructed disk and find the closest match to estimate the turbidity value. If the pattern is not observable through 100 mL of water, pour off 5 mL of water and observe the 0 NTU pattern again. Keep doing this until the pattern is visible. Record the volume left in the cylinder and estimate the turbidity value.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Quality of Surface Waters: Physical and Chemical investigation (item number 580831) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company. Call: 866-332-4478 to order.

Wear your safety goggles, gloves, and lab apron any time you are dealing with chemicals, including the LaMotte<sup>®</sup> TesTabs<sup>®</sup>. Natural water samples can contain harmful contaminates and organisms. Wear your gloves and safety goggles during sample collection as well.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

Never conduct fieldwork on your own, especially in remote areas; always take a responsible partner with you. Prepare and leave a field safety plan, complete with planned survey locations and expected return time, with a responsible party. Wear appropriate clothing (long pants and close-toed shoes are usually best), sunblock, and insect repellant if necessary. Be familiar with the potential hazards in your chosen survey areas. Please review the “Field Work” portion of the Laboratory Safety Manual or your school’s specific safety guidelines for more information. Make sure that you are healthy enough to participate in fieldwork. If in doubt, consult your medical practitioner.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is NOT a safety requirement when conducting field work in remote areas?

options.text: Disinfect all samples thoroughly with bleach upon your return.
Take a responsible partner along with you.
Prepare a written safety plan and leave it with a responsible party.
Wear appropriate clothing such as long pants and outdoor shoes.
Familiarize yourself with any potential hazards in your chosen survey area.

assestmentData.question: Out of the 75% of the earth's surface that is covered by water, what percentage of that water is freshwater?
How many times more acidic is water with a pH of 3.5 than water with a pH of 5.5?
The addition of water-soluble nitrates and phosphates from fertilizers into water systems directly increases the rate of which of the following?
Which of the following is usually the limiting nutrient in freshwater?
Which of the following is used to determine the turbidity of a water sample in this investigation?
Which of the following processes is NOT determined by temperature in an aquatic ecosystem?

options.text: the solubility of oxygen in water
the rate of photosynthesis in aquatic plants
the metabolic rate of aquatic organisms
the susceptibility of aquatic species to toxins and disease

assestmentData.question: Dissolved oxygen (DO) in water mostly comes from which of the following sources?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

typeBefore.text: Select your field sites for the following activities. This kit has enough test materials for two separate sample locations. You will perform all six activities for your first sample before collecting a second sample at a second site and performing the activities again.

pageData.text: Ideal water sources include shallow creeks, rivers, springs, or ponds. Locate several possible test sites on a map in case one of the sites isn’t ideal for sampling once you visit it in person. Also, make sure these areas are accessible to you. Sites located in county or state parks are accessible, but for visiting privately owned sites, you will need to acquire permission from landowners.

Activities 1 and 2 will be performed at the field site. Activities 3–6 can be performed at the field site or at home within 2–3 hours of sample collection. It is common practice to use a cooler to transport samples because they need to be kept cool and dark to prevent post-sampling photosynthesis from skewing test results.

Select an area to test based on the way the watershed flows. Choosing sites above and below the convergence of two waterways helps pinpoint the source of any pollution found in the samples. Prepare a map that marks the chosen sites. Each site can be identified with latitude and longitude using a GPS or GPS-enabled phone. If using the Google Maps app on an iOs smart phone, drop a pin at your desired location and scroll up from the menu bar at the bottom to see the coordinates. Simply look in the search box at the top, using an Android smart phone.

Determine the approximate altitude of the sample locations. There are several websites that can help you identify the altitude of a pinned location (e.g., https://www.freemaptools.com/elevation-finder.htm and https://www.daftlogic.com/sandbox-google-maps-find-altitude.htm). There are also free apps for smart phones, such as “My Altitude” app for iOS and the “Get Altitude” app for Android. You can also determine your altitude once you arrive at your destination if you have an iOS device. The elevation can be determined by using the “Compass” app for iOS. Make sure your location services are enabled for the “Compass” app, open the app, and the elevation will be listed at the bottom, along with the coordinates for your current location.
Read through the activities.

Obtain all materials that you need before starting the field trip. Make sure that you have the LaMotte® TesTabs®, a pipet, the water-resistant sample comparison sheets, Table 1 and Data Table 1, a thermometer, sterile water sample collection bottles, aluminum foil, gloves, goggles, apron, a permanent marker, and a cooler with ice if you will be transporting samples.

At the test location, collect each sample from a location that is representative of the waterway according to the activity instructions. Best results will be obtained if samples are collected from locations that are not close to stormwater drains and drainage ditches. For the most reliable results, water samples should be collected midstream. Water near the shore generally is not representative of an entire stream or river, because some runoff is highly concentrated and has not yet mixed with the main body of water.

IMPORTANT : In some situations (e.g., if the water is too deep), it may not be possible, feasible, or safe to obtain an ideal sample. If in doubt of the depth or safety of the water, DO NOT try to collect a sample from that location. Instead, collect a water sample from a location you are sure is safe.
In Activity 1, you will measure the temperature of the water at your chosen test location.
While wearing gloves and goggles, submerge the thermometer 4 inches below the surface of the body of water.
Keep the thermometer in the water for 2 minutes. Remove it from the water and immediately record the water temperature at this site in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: In Activity 2, you will collect a water sample from your chosen test location. You will test this water sample’s physical and chemical properties in subsequent activities.
While wearing gloves and goggles, remove the lid from the 125 mL sampling container.
Rinse the container two or three times with water from the sample site.
Replace the lid.
Plunge the sample bottle several inches under the surface of the water.
Remove the lid.
Turn the bottle into the current, if there is one, and allow the water to fill the container. Hold the sample container underwater for at least 30 seconds.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Replace the cap while the bottle is still submerged. There should be no air left in the bottle.
This sample will be used for Activities 3–6.
Note: The remaining tests can be conducted indoors. The sample can be transported in a cooler back to your home environment if you so choose. Or, the remaining tests can be performed at the site.
In Activity 3, you will use pH paper to measure the pH of your water sample.
Wear gloves, goggles, and a lab apron when performing tests on the field site water.
Tear off a strip of pH paper from the pack provided.
Use a plastic pipet to squeeze up a few drops of the water sample that you collected in Activity 2.
Release a drop of water from the pipet onto the piece of pH paper to dampen it.
Compare the resulting color to the pH color chart. Take a photograph of your sample being held up to the pH color chart.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Record the pH for this water site in Data Table 1.
In Activity 4, you will observe the color change after adding a LaMotte<sup>®</sup> Phosphorous TesTab<sup>®</sup> to your water sample to determine its phosphorous content.
Wear gloves, goggles, and a lab apron when performing tests on the field site water.
Label one of the 15 mL conical tubes “Phosphate Test.”
Fill the tube to the 10 mL line with the water sample from the collection bottle.

Add one LaMotte<sup>®</sup> Phosphorous TesTab<sup>®</sup>, cap the tube tightly, and mix the sample by repeatedly turning the tube upside down and righting it until the tablet is broken up. Some chunks of the tablet may remain, but most of it should dissolve.
Wait 5 minutes for the color to develop.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Compare the color of the sample to the phosphate colors on the Sample Comparison Chart. Take a photograph of your sample being held up to the chart. Record the result as ppm of phosphate in Data Table 1. If a blue color does not develop, record the result as “0 ppm.”
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In Activity 5, you will observe the color change after adding a LaMotte<sup>®</sup> Nitrate TesTab<sup>®</sup> to your water sample to determine its nitrate content.
Tear off a piece of aluminum foil large enough to wrap the other conical tube.
Wear gloves, goggles, and a lab apron when performing tests on the field site water.
Label the other 15 mL conical tube “Nitrate Test.”
Fill the tube to the 5 mL line from the collection bottle.
Add one Nitrate TesTab<sup>®</sup>.

Cap the tube tightly and mix the sample by repeatedly turning the tube upside down and righting it for
2 minutes until the tablet is broken up. Some chunks of the tablet may remain, but most of it should dissolve.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Wrap the tube completely in aluminum foil.
Wait 5 minutes for the color to develop.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Remove the tube from the aluminum foil.
Compare the color of the sample to the nitrate color on the Sample Comparison Chart. Take a photograph of your sample being held up to the chart. Record the result as ppm of nitrate in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In Activity 6, you will determine the turbidity of your water sample by observing Secchi disk patterns through your sample.
While wearing gloves and goggles, fill the graduated cylinder from your equipment kit to the 100 mL mark with sample water from your collection bottle.

Remove the cylinder from its base and place it over the black and white pattern of the “0 NTU” <button class='glossary-text'>turbidity</button> part of the Sample Comparison Chart. This pattern, along with the “8 NTU” and “18 NTU” turbidity part of the chart, are acting as Secchi disks in this lab.

Look straight down through the water sample and observe the “0 NTU” pattern through the water column (see Figure 4). If you can see the pattern clearly, proceed to Step 3a. If you cannot see the pattern, proceed to Step 3b.
  1. Looking straight down through the water sample, compare the appearance of the pattern you see to the disk patterns of 0 NTU, 8 NTU, and 18 NTU on your chart. In Data Table 1, record a turbidity value (NTU) that most closely matches what you see through the column of water.
    • If the appearance of the pattern does not exactly match one of the 3 disk icons, evaluate between which 2 icons the appearance of the pattern is an intermediate and then approximate the turbidity as somewhere between the NTU values of those icons.
    • If the appearance of the pattern is lighter than the 18 NTU icon but still visible, approximate the turbidity as somewhere between 18 and 29 NTU.
  2. Pour off 5 mL of water. Look through the cylinder again. If you still cannot see the pattern, continue to pour off water in 5 mL increments until you can barely see the pattern (it may appear fuzzy, but you will be able to make out the pattern. See Figure 4.)

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Photograph looking down into a graduated cylinder to see the ‘fuzzy’ pattern of the Secchi disk.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Photograph looking down into a graduated cylinder to see the ‘fuzzy’ pattern of the Secchi disk.

pageData.text: 1. In Data Table 1, record the highest volume of water left in the graduated cylinder through which you can see the pattern.
1. Estimate the turbidity NTU by comparing the volume to the volume in Table 1. Record the NTU in Data Table 1.
IMPORTANT : Be sure to collect a second sample from a different location and perform all six activities again for this new sample.

Dispose of solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions. If tests were performed in the field, dump all solutions into a ‘waste container’ to be dumped down a drain with the water running upon arrival back to your home. Throw away all other materials from the materials kit in the household trash.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: Rinse the equipment from the equipment kit with tap water, allow to dry, and return the materials to your equipment kit.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
Sanitize the work space and wash your hands thoroughly.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.altText: completion

pageData.content: Figure 1. Percent water abundance by source
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Three column graphs illustrating the percent composition of total global water, freshwater, and surface water and other fresh water, respectively. The freshwater column is an expansion of 2.5% of the total global water column. The surface water and other fresh water column is an expansion of 1.2% of the freshwater column.
Figure 2: A diagram of the eutrophication process.

pageData.content: Figure 3. The pH scale and household items by pH
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A pH scale showing the pHs of common household substances.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 1-4 of this investigation. Before beginning, locate several possible test sites and determine the approximate altitude of each. Then, obtain your field work materials and travel to your test site. In activity 1, submerge the thermometer in the test site water and record the water temperature. In activity 2, rinse the sampling container in the test site water and collect site water. If you are conducting activities 3-6 on site, continue to activity 3. If not, transport your sample home in a cooler, then continue to activity 3. In activity 3, you will add a drop of ample water to the pH paper, compare it to the color chart and record the water pH.  In activity 4, fill the conical tube with sample water, add the LaMotte® Phosphorus TesTab® to the tube and mix the contents. Once a color has developed, compare the tube color to the Sample comparison chart and record the ppm of phosphate in the water sample.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 5 and 6 of this investigation. After completing activity 4, in activity 5, wrap a conical tube in aluminum foil, fill it with sample water, add a LaMotte® Nitrate TesTab® to the tube and mix. Once color has developed, remove the foil, compare the tube color to the Sample comparison chart and record the ppm of phosphate in the water sample. In activity 6, fill the graduated cylinder with 100 mL of water. Then, remove the cylinder from its base and place it over the 0 NTU pattern. Next, observe the pattern through the water. If the pattern is observable, compare the appearance of the 0 NTU pattern through the water to each unobstructed disk and find the closest match to estimate the turbidity value. If the pattern is not observable through 100 mL of water, pour off 5 mL of water and observe the 0 NTU pattern again. Keep doing this until the pattern is visible. Record the volume left in the cylinder and estimate the turbidity value.
Figure 4: Photograph looking down into a graduated cylinder to see the ‘fuzzy’ pattern of the Secchi disk.

data.title: Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)
data.content: The amount of dissolved oxygen needed by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample; also called biological oxygen demand

data.title: Dissolved oxygen (DO)
data.content: The amount of oxygen in water

data.title: Eutrophication
data.content: An increase in nutrients in a body of water leading to excessive growth of algal and plant species which often results in the die off of other species due to increased turbidity and lower dissolved oxygen

data.title: Total suspended solids (TSS)
data.content: A term used to describe and measure the material left behind after a water sample has been filtered and evaporated

data.title: Turbidity
data.content: Cloudiness in a solution that is a result of small particles in suspension
